Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Looking at the sample events provided, each event has a timestamp, activity, resource, and additional info. From these, I should see patterns. First, looking at the events in Case A1 and B2, maybe common steps emerge.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Looking at B2 events: they involve similar steps like getting another sheet, scanning, placing, aligning again, preheating, coating, checking. So it seems like after getting the raw sheet, the sequence could be preparing to weld.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: The manufacturing process might have steps like: Material Preparation, Assembly, Quality Inspection. Looking at the A1 events, steps could be: Retrieve raw metal sheet as Material Prep, etc.

Name: Backtracking - IND
Text: Alternatively, looking at the A1 events: After getting the raw sheet, they do scanner, place on table, align metal sheet, preheat, apply coating, dry coat, check. Maybe this sequence is about setting up the sheet for assembly. Wait perhaps A1 is preparing for assembly.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - IND
Text: Suppose High-Level steps: 1. Material Preparation (universal starting point) 2. Assembly Setup 3. Quality Control. But maybe more specific.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Now, lets check the samples data. For A1 events, if grouping them under Preparation includes material retrieval, placing on table, etc., then that works.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Proposed High-Level Steps: 1. Preparation - Grouping all events related to getting raw materials, setting up the workspace, positioning components. 2. Assembly 3. Quality Assurance.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - IND
Text: To keep it simple, let me just pick Preparation and Assembly as the two high-level steps. Then rationale: Preparation groups all the setup actions. Assembly groups the assembly steps.
